body:
I am reading how to improve the testing execution time, because the tests
themselves are consuming most of the time during the Travis-Ci job task
execution.

As reference:

https://docs.gradle.org/7.2/userguide/java_testing.html#sec:test_execution
https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-parallel-execution


Regards

Victor

El lun, 25 oct 2021 a las 2:39, Avik Ganguly ***@***.***>)
escribió:

> @fintecheando <https://github.com/fintecheando> (cc @ptuomola
> <https://github.com/ptuomola> @awasum <https://github.com/awasum>) :
> Thank you for adding SonarQube! Do you have any inputs for reducing test
> time

Found the missing line - now single calls work...

@ptuomola @fynmanoj @IOhacker :

This is the approximate list of flaky tests which new contributors have to pass to get a green build : -

1. ClientSavingsIntegrationTest. testSavingsAccount_DormancyTracking()
2. FinancialActivityAccountsTest. testFinancialActivityAccounts()
3.GlobalConfigInterestChargedFromDateSameAsDisbursalDateTest.testInterestChargedFromDateSameAsDisbursalDate()
4. GlobalConfigurationTest. testGlobalConfigForcePasswordResetDays()
5. GlobalConfigurationTest. testGlobalConfigurationIsCacheEnabled()
6. GlobalConfigurationTest. testGlobalConfigurations()
7. creditBureauConfigurationTest
8. LoanReschedulingWithinCenterTest. testCenterReschedulingLoansWithInterestRecalculationEnabled()
9. LoanReschedulingWithinCenterTest. testCenterReschedulingMultiTrancheLoansWithInterestRecalculationEnabled()
10. SavingsAccountsTest. activateSavingsAccount()
11. SavingsAccountsTest. approveSavingsAccount()
12. SavingsAccountsTest. submitSavingsAccountsApplication()
13. SchedulerJobsTest. testDateFormat()
14. SchedulerJobsTest. testFlippingJobsActiveStatus()
15. SchedulerJobsTest. testNumberOfJobs()
16. SchedulerJobsTest. testTriggeringManualExecutionOfAllSchedulerJobs()
17. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testApplyAnnualFeeForSavingsJobOutcome()
18. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testApplyDueFeeChargesForSavingsJobOutcome()
19. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testApplyHolidaysToLoansJobOutcome()
20. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testApplyPenaltyForOverdueLoansJobOutcome()

22. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testExecuteStandingInstructionsJobOutcome()
23. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testInterestPostingForSavingsJobOutcome()
24. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testInterestTransferForSavings()
25. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testTransferFeeForLoansFromSavingsJobOutcome()
26. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testUpdateAccountingRunningBalancesJobOutcome()
27. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testUpdateLoanArrearsAgingJobOutcome()
28. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testUpdateLoanPaidInAdvanceJobOutcome()
29. SchedulerJobsTestResults. testUpdateOverdueDaysForNPA()
Now trying to find some way to fix this classpath nightmare

@avikganguly01 I've just looked through the last couple of dozen or so failed builds, and did not see any of the ones on this list. Perhaps you could flag when you next see one of these failing, and we can then investigate & fix the root cause.
Ok - hopefully have now fixed the classpath issues. Let's see if this works.

@ptuomola ... please check this for the Jersey configuration: https://github.com/FITER1/fineract-ng/blob/feature/01-migration-eclipse-link/fineract-provider/src/main/java/org/apache/fineract/infrastructure/core/boot/JerseyConfiguration.java

I'll have also a look at the classpath issues... I remember that I fixed something similar by cleaning up all the dependencies (that was before the major improvements happened after version 1.3)... so, the Gradle file in that branch is very different from what we have now upstream, but maybe it contains part of the solution... just as a caveat.

Thanks! I think I actually found a simpler solution: if you just do package() with the root package then all the classes get automatically found. 

Also fixed the classpath issues. Now just need to debug the failing integration tests...

@ptuomola  @awasum  : Travis isn't running again. Is this related to bottlenecks on Apache Infra side? If yes, can we move this from Apache infra to some infrastructure which I can provide you access to?

Ankita has tried triggering the build in different ways by pushing commits but no luck so far. Gradle test locally (without the fail fast flag) is failing with some of the flaky tests communicated earlier. We have no way of knowing whether build is going to be triggered and whether it will pass after merging. I have ran the charge specific integration tests separately one by one and they are passing though. I would like to merge it based on the time sensitivity of this rollout in production but  I will hold onto it till you get an opportunity to comment.

@avikganguly01 Travis build triggered - let's see if it is passes

And for local builds you need to always start with a new empty database. Otherwise they will not pass.
Looks like the build failed due to Docker rate limit. Let's retry...
Looks like the build passed. That's great.
Need to first resolve the incompatibilities in the config - see #1867

Even though the build works, the debug is not picking up the latest changes... so still something wrong with the paths. Will need to investigate further.
This now works for me locally - just need to see if the tests pass here as well.
Actually - I was wrong. Seems to be working fine, so ready to be merged.
Version 8 does not support MySQL 5.7, so we first need to upgrade MySQL...
Closing and reopening

@IOhacker I think we should also update README.md to give people instructions to use MariaDB rather than MySQL, and .travis.yml to use MariaDB.

Concept looks OK, but I think there's a problem in the docker-compose.yml:

ERROR: The Compose file './docker-compose.yml' is invalid because:
services.community-app.depends_on contains an invalid type, it should be an array
services.fineract-server.depends_on contains an invalid type, it should be an array

Hello,

It is because the version of Docker Compose in Travis-Ci, I will send a fix
in the travis yml

Yes.

Ideally Fineract would respect the tenant tile zones configured in the
database, and then the server time zone would not matter.

However this is not working 100%. Consequently a number of the integration
tests fail intermittently if the server time zone is not the same as the
tenant time zone.

As our integration tests use tenant time zone as Asia/Kolkata, we need to
set the server timezone to be the same to avoid "flakiness" of tests

If you look in the Travis CI script you can see the same setting hardcoded
there.

Yes spot on - that’s actually the problem I have not yet managed to resolve
with this migration to GitHub Actions.

That token is actually already encrypted. Travis has a feature to decrypt
it before using, hence it’s safe to add it there.

But Github does not have such feature, hence Sonarqube as git action is
currently failing as it can’t use the encrypted token.

The three options that I can see to implement the same on GitHub are:

1. Use Github secrets. But my understanding is that  that’s not allowed for
Apache repos

2. Use Sonarqubes GitHub app. Again, not allowed as far as I know

3. Put the token as plaintext. Insecure, so really not a good plan.

So I think for now I’ll focus on trying to get the build to run in GitHub
Actions. We can leave Sonarqube on Travis for now, until someone comes up
with a good idea on how to solve this.
